text: All right, I guess we'll get started.
Um, yeah, thanks for coming to my talk.
I hope you're all having a really good
first day of sessions and enjoying
UEFest.
Um, yeah, so today we're going to talk
about real world implementation of Simpy
2110 for ICVX.
Um this is more targeted towards virtual
production whether it's for film, TV,
commercials, other applications of it.
Um I'm assuming that everyone here has
um some knowledge of and experience with
end display already.
Um
so we'll go through a quick overview of
SIMD210. What is it? Um how it compares
to previous systems and setups.
um how you design for it um and
especially one of the features I think
is kind of underutilized the split inner
frustm um and then go into some
practical like tips and like testing
troubleshooting
um things that we found out in
production that I'm hoping will make
other people trying to use it um give
them some tips to actually put into
practice.
So, a bit about me. Um, my name is Julia
Louu. I'm a virtual production
supervisor. Um, I specialize mostly in
engine technical onset supervision. Um,
I've done lots of jobs like um tools
developer, R&D. Um, was an engine
operator and on set soup. Um, mostly
using VR, AR like app development. um
viz, whether it's pre viz, tech viz,
onset viz, um ICVFX of course and
virtual art department at studios like
digital domain deneg um let's see the
third floor lux machina and currently
Netflix.
Um yeah so what about that?
So, the system that we tested all of
this on was the Chinachita uh stage 18
LED volume um in Rome. It's quite a big
volume. It's 25 m uh diameter with 8 m
tall and it's got five nodes for the
main wall, one node for the ceiling, and
then um a wild wall. And then we had
spares as well. So it's quite high
resolution is 18K total for the width of
the main wall. Um and we implemented
this early in 2024 around like February
2024 was when we started implementing
SIMD into an existing system. Um and
then we shot with it in production on a
feature at the end of last year. Um so
we were able to achieve an 8K
interference whereas before we were more
doing like a UHD sort of resolution. Um
this was tested with dual 6000 ADAS on
all the nodes. Um previously it had been
a multi-process setup. Um we'll go into
that in a bit and this was tested with
UE54.
So what is SIMD210?
So it's a video standard, audio and
video standard um that replaces
traditional analog signals like SDI um
for distributing video. Um so instead of
like your SDI cables, you splitters and
your video hub and everything um this
sends everything over the network. So
you're sending it over switches, over
network adapters, over optical fiber.
Um, so there's lots of benefits to that
and we'll go into that um in a sec. Um,
but basically it breaks down each frame
into packets and then streams them
across as fast as it can. Um, and then
sync is handled um by the time stamp in
the header um of each packet. And uh
there's a session description protocol.
It's a file that's gets streamed as well
that describes what kind of stream
you're sending. So information like the
resolution um the color like what
channels are in there um all that
information.
So while SDI you had to specify well
each port specifies whether it's an
input or an output um simply 2110 can be
birectional so you can send and receive
on the same port um which is quite
powerful that also makes it very
flexible and easy to scale. Um whereas
before you were kind of constrained by
how many ports say you had available on
your video matrix, now it's just how
many ports do you have on your switch
and how much bandwidth do you have to
add more devices. Um so that makes it um
very dynamic and you can add like
patching a signal isn't a physical patch
anymore. You just change the multiccast
address um tell the receiver to look for
the same address and then that's how you
connect a stream.
So, how is this integrated into Unreal?
So, Unreal uses uh the RiverMax
implementation of SIMD 2110,
specifically Simpy 211020, which is for
uncompressed video. Um, we're usually
looking for RGB 10 bit um when using it
for ICVX. you can configure it
differently, but that's probably the
most common case. Um, it does require
specific hardware um especially for the
network adapters. So, connectex adapters
um and blue field if you're doing PTP
timing and these handle like the
encoding and decoding of the video
signal. Um, and for Unreal, it does uh
depend quite heavily on the engine
version, which version of all your
drivers and stuff um the SDK version uh
to use. That's something to be aware of,
not just install the latest one uh
because it might not work. But you can
use it as um in a variety of
applications like it can be used as a
media texture. You could plug it into
say like a material and just apply a
material with a stream. Say if you have
like a TV in your scene or something. Um
or you could do it as an output if you
wanted to render your viewport or camera
and send it out. Um or there's the end
display use.
So comparing it to previous systems. Um
so typical previous end display systems
would have done like single GPUs
probably the simplest use case that's
where everything is rendered on one GPU
and sent out um via the output. Then
there was multi-GPU where you had two
GPUs or more per machine um and they
were connected via SLI. So then you
could have the interfostum um render on
the second GPU and share it to the first
um and then send it out for output.
or there was multiprocess
um which is also two or more GPUs but
it's split into two different processes.
So you have the first process rendering
the outer frustm and then a headless um
instance of Unreal rendering the inner
frostm
with simply 2110 you can get a lot more
different configurations. So like these
are all examples of like what a config
might look like. Um you could do a
single tile. You could have one node
dedicated to the inner node and it's
rendering the whole interferm on one GPU
and then sending it out to all of the
inner nodes which then do the composite
um and then send it out. Or you could
have it split into two different GPUs on
one um inner node and it sends that out
as two streams and then the outer node
composits it or you can expand it. We
had uh two machines with two GPUs each.
So we were able to get four tiles and
then you can use these in any sort of
configuration. So you could have two
GPUs rendering two tiles and then one
GPU rendering a full separate other
frostm if you wanted. Um you don't
really need to do any like repatching or
anything to get it to work. You just set
it into your config and set the
multiccast addresses.
Like one thing to be aware of is that
with separate processes they do share
the same CPU and memory resources. So if
your content is like CPUbound or
something maybe like it wouldn't be good
idea to run multiple processes on it but
that's more an issue of optimization I
think.
So previous sync and signal distribution
needed physical cables from each GPU
output to the processor or your video
matrix. If you're doing a full simpy
setup um that's no longer the case. it
would just be done over the network and
then um your processor would need to be
able to um receive simply 2110 streams
as well. Um we no longer need um each
node to render a copy of the inner
frostm. So in case um like cost was an
issue, you could just not have a second
GPU in all of your outer frustm nodes.
Um,
and then for you also needed trile sync
throughout your system. So then you
needed like your genlock signal coming
into like a sync card on each machine
that's then daisy changed and
everything. Um, if you're doing a full
setup um, then um, PTP would handle that
and that's sent over multiccast as well.
Um, you also needed to have like EDID
set for all of your outputs. configure
mosaic um with simpy that you don't
really need that everything is running
headless if it's sending a simp network
uh signal so you don't have to do that
process anymore
that kind of configures that
um another cool thing is that you can
change the resolution of an output um in
the session um because it's defined in
the STP um when you do that it might
stutter but then it'll update and then
start sending the stream and all the
nodes will read the STP and look for
that resolution instead. Um like media
textures and media output sources um
they adapt to the resolution
automatically.
Um
yeah, one thing that is useful is that
um if you configure all your nodes in
exactly the same way, say you can get
two GPUs per node, then all of your
nodes are interchangeable. Like you can
swap an inner node with an outer custom
node. Um you can have spares that could
stand in for any of the nodes in the
system. So that's one thing to note for
flexibility.
So designing for simply 2110
um I think for a simpy system there's
definitely use cases where you'll see
more benefits um especially for larger
volume volumes um or flexible like
pop-up style or like mobile volumes or
reconfigurable ones um that'll save a
lot of patching um video cables and
stuff um and be able to do that quickly
and you can also scale up much more
easily. Um, and also for full 3D content
is a good application of it, especially
with the split interf um because you get
a lot more render power. Um, if you're
doing like plate playback or something,
you might not see as much benefit
because the resolution is already baked
in. And also like if you're using EXRs,
the processing already handles like
splitting into tiles and streaming that
in an optimized way already.
So integration of 2110. Um it depends on
whether it's like a new build. Maybe you
want to go all in on 2110 from the start
or if you already have an existing
system with existing hardware. Maybe
there's some bits that are harder harder
to replace than others. Like in our case
um we didn't own the video processor so
we couldn't swap those out very easily.
Um but um yeah, so it depends on whether
you want to do a full switch or like
it's it's a new build or if you need to
integrate into existing systems. And
also to consider whether there's other
departments say on set or something that
will want to receive the stream as well
like if it's for monitoring um like if
you want to send the feed to video
village or something if they can receive
a simp stream or if you need to convert
it um to something like SDI for them.
And also another thing to consider is
like available slots and ports depending
on your um needs for your nodes. like if
you have capture cards in them, um is
there going to be space for like two
GPUs and a network card and any other
network adapters uh for other networks?
Um if you need a sync card, um yeah, we
had some fun playing Tetris trying to
fit everything onto one motherboard.
Um I'll just touch on PTP a bit. Um I
think this could probably be a talk on
itself. um configuring PTP and like the
grandmaster and everything. Um but
there's lots of good videos on YouTube
that talk about it. Um so that's
precision time protocol um that syncs um
all of the video signals um using
multiccast. It um sends a sync signal
and then waits for um well it gets a
reply um from each of the nodes that
would say like yes I'm in sync and like
checks for drift and everything. Um, one
thing to consider is that Bluefield 2 um
is reaching end of life very soon. I
think the it's supposed to be August, so
maybe already. Um, but Bluefield 3 is
supported um with Unreal and River.
So, bandwidth and networking. So, since
everything is on the network, the
network configuration is going to be
very important. Um, you need to get
switches that are compatible with
SIMP210.
Um, and if you need to, um, that can
support PDP as well. Um, especially
things like flow control, IGMP,
snooping, multiccast settings, like
you'll be able you'll want to be able to
manage those and configure it to um,
make sure that you're not seeing things
like jitter and drop packets um, on your
network. Um, we also found that like
mixing speeds on your switch doesn't
work very well because it will randomly
discard packets to try and reach the
lowest um speed. Um, so then you'll see
like carrying and all sorts of ugly
artifacts if you try doing that. So
definitely spend the money to get a good
switch. Um, and have your transceivers
match the switch speed as well.
Um, another thing that we found was that
um, if the network card is say close to
the GPUs, there's a chance it could
overheat
um, which will also cause packets to
drop. So that's another thing when
figuring out your motherboard layout.
So how much bandwidth do you need? Um,
generally it's going to be like the
dimensions in pixels times the bit depth
times the number of channels plus the
frame rate that it's sending at. Um,
when using it for ICV effects, we
actually want to send faster um than our
show frame rate. So, say we were sending
at 60 fps. That way, there's enough time
for the entire frame to arrive in time
for it to get composited and displayed.
Um, so it was rendering at 24, but it
would send at 60 Hz. Um, so typically
you'd want something that's like 100
Gbit per second or more.
Um, another thing that is quite
important is to separate your networks.
Um, if you have this blasting streams
left and right, um, any other network
traffic is kind of going to get stuck in
it. Um, so if you're doing things like
remoting into your operating machine or
something, it's going to make the editor
very hard to use if you're you haven't
separated out your networks. So use
VLANs for sure. Separate out your
tracking data, any like iPad controls,
DMX. Um, make sure those are on separate
networks. Um, and if you're using
Melanox cards, there's two ports on it
on the network card. So that gives you
an option. So you could have two simpy
networks or you could have one for simp
and then one for um another use case.
Um so in RiverMax there's a technology
called GPU direct which is another
optimization. Um instead of transferring
the data from like the network card to
the CPU to the GPU, it just goes
straight between the network card and
the GPU. So GPU direct like handles
allocating memory. Um it gives you a
little bit of a performance boost. I
think we were seeing about like two or
four frames per second. Um which is
pretty good. I mean every frame helps.
And then it is important to consider
that um then your GPU and network card
uh to use this benefit need to be on the
same bus. So check that they're under
the same root complex.
um like check the motherboard manual for
the layout to see which bus everything
is on. Um and then there's a C bar where
you can turn it off globally um in the
engine. Um or there's tick boxes on each
of the inputs or um like river max
sources where you can tick whether to
use it or not. But that's just a quick C
bar to test.
Um, another consideration definitely is
power. So the first time we booted up
the full cluster with all five nodes in
the ceiling and the two inner nodes, we
tripped the alarm saying that we were
drawing too much power. Um, so that is
definitely something to think about. Um,
another thing is to use system images if
you can. um because it's a lot of
configuration on each node and if you
miss a setting on one node, you'll be
hunting through all of them trying to
find like which one is missing this one
stupid tick box. So use system images
just to make sure that all your systems
are set up the same.
So the split interferm or the tiled
interferm um the main use for this is
you get a boost in performance and then
you can achieve higher resolution.
So, like one of the most common
complaints about using ICVF effects and
shooting with LED is that the background
looks soft and like you're kind of
constrained by the performance of your
machine and how high of a resolution it
can render before you start dropping
frames and start seeing like stutters.
So, splitting the interface across GPUs,
you get a lot more render power. Um
like our previous solution to this um on
those about to die was just to use the
entire wall as a frustm basically and we
tracked the outer frustm um which then
gave us high resolution but then you
lose things like depth of field.
Everything is on like the same focus
plane. Um and you can't easily turn on
like make the the frustm blue or turn on
chroma. you'd have to like put something
there or turn the frustm back on and
then switch it to chroma. Um, and you
also lose some color correction
abilities like um, one thing that some
DBs do is they'll grade certain um,
sections of the wall and they'll like
use that to grade their shadows or
something. But if your entire wall is
your frustm, you can't really easily um,
switch an entire section of it to a
different color. Um so splitting the
inner frostm um takes care of like those
issues and it gives us more render
power.
So like how do we split it? Um I think
the most common configuration for like
if you're doing four tiles is just to
split it in a cross. Um which makes
sense. Um but you can also split it in
different directions if say you're
seeing artifacts. um like depending on
your camera move um you can have it go
in a different direction. So like if
you're doing a horizontal split um you
can fix things that are issues on
vertical seams um especially if your
camera's panning. So then it's because
it's moving along the same direction of
the seams. You won't see those as
prominently or like um the same for
vertical split for um horizontal seams.
And then like operating a simply 2110
cluster for like engine TDs and
operators is generally going to be the
same as operating another end display
setup. Um there are some things to keep
in mind with like setting resolution and
overcan and such. Um, so you can set
your custom resolution on the ICVFX
camera component in the custom
resolution section. Um, and then you can
increase the screen percentage um to do
a multiplier on it. Um,
and then is it one thing to note is that
like if you change the resolution or
something during the session, you are
going to get like a stutter while it
updates. So, best not to do it in the
middle of a take. Um,
but you can change things like the
overcan if you turn adapt resolution
off. So, if you're like in the middle of
a take and you see the camera is about
to go out out of the frustm, you can
increase the overcan a bit and that will
be fine.
So building content for the split interf
I think most of these things are best
practice for end display anyway like if
you were say doing a multiprocess or
multi-GPU setup you would still have
issues with like the nodes rendering
non-deterministically or something. So
these things are still best practice. Um
but with the split interf
screen space effects. Um things like
bloom vignette, screen space fog, SSAO,
SSAO you might be able to get away with
if you have a really tiny radius, but um
yeah, best not to use it. Um, instead
try to look for things that are using
like rolled um, camera view or
projection clip space instead. So you
could still do like post-process and
stuff, just try to use those faces
instead of screen space.
Another thing to use is overcan. It
helps blend the seams between each of
the tiles because it'll be a hard line
where the seam is. There isn't like a
feather or anything in there. Now, um so
you can over scan a little bit to help
fix like especially things like culling
and like lighting artifacts. Um it'll
help those blend a little bit. Um the
cool thing is that it over only overcans
on the um seam the interior seams. So
it's not like overcanning outside the
frustr
losing resolution there. So it's just
where the overlaps are.
Um, Niagara effects, of course, they
should be deterministic.
Um, if say you're using PCG or
something, um, if you've cached it, it's
probably fine, but if it's like
regenerating PCG, you probably want that
to be deterministic as well. Um, and to
set your sort priorities on things like
post-process
um, and translucent materials,
especially big things like say you have
volumetrics that are like fog or
something and you have multiple layers
of fog, you want to set your priority so
it knows which one to draw on top and
like um, that order is consistent.
Otherwise, you'll see some mismatches
between the tiles.
So blueprinting for split interferm
um I think it's usually the ones that
are driven by time that are most likely
to have seen in them um where some of
them might be like slightly off
especially if it's like doing something
on the transform like the translation or
rotation or something.
Um, some things might be easier to do
um, using sequencer if you're trying to
do something like very precise timing.
Um, but if it's something that's just
like in the background, just something
moving to give it a bit of life, you
could do it um, in a blueprint.
Uh, I don't recommend using timelines.
They tend to be quite heavy. Um, like
um, they're also quite hard to control
sometimes. So try to avoid timeline
nodes whenever you can.
The way I usually go about making
blueprints for um the system is to use
the um tickable actor class as a base.
Um usually the first one, the one that's
highlighted, the view VP viewport ticket
tickable um actor base, that one works
both in editor and on the wall. So you
can see it updating in your editor on
tick as well. Um like generally you
don't want to have too many actors that
are ticking. So you could have one
controller that's using this base class
updating like a bunch of instances of um
your actors in the scene. Um and it's
pretty easy to use. Like it just exposes
the event editor tick and then you can
connect connect that like you would um
like with your regular tick event.
Um, another thing that's helpful is to
use the time code node. Um, you can feed
that either into an actor with a
blueprint or you can like feed it into
your materials. Um, so then that can
drive like a material or actor using
time because it's time code and if you
have time code across your system, all
of the nodes will be using the same time
code to update with.
Um, you can also use the delta time um
because you're going to have gen lock
and sync and all that. So the delta time
will always be the time of one frame.
Um, so in case you do have cases where
you're updating a blueprint and then you
see it mismatches across nodes, um,
there are some components that you can
use um, on your actor, the sync
components that will um, sync over um,
the end display cluster. Um, so you can
add those to your blueprint.
Um and also using random values is a big
one that can sometimes be
non-deterministic.
So use um the random stream um that you
can set a seed on it. You can set a seed
value for to start generating the
numbers from um and you have all your
different data types like float, int,
whatever you want. Um so use those
instead.
So like we were using lumen and ray
tracing nanite all that um lumen
particularly like some of the parts of
it are temporal so like you'll get some
um seams as it's updating
um so one way to fix this is to increase
the lumen update speed and the final
gather update speed. So that will make
Lumen update the scene faster, but it
doesn't have a cost on performance. Um,
so adjust it as high as you can get
without dropping frames. Um, another big
one for artists is that you need to
disable screen traces because it's a
screen space effect. Um, it does make
your reflections look very pretty, but
it causes lots of seams in a split
interface. So, um, it's best to build
the content with that in mind, not to
use that feature.
So, upscaling and denoising. Again,
these are temporal. So, if you're using
like TSR or something, you may see like
a trail as like the FTOM moves. Um, I
think where is you could see it slightly
on here. Um, you can see as it passes
across like that door. um you see like a
shadow moving across that's where the
theme is. Um so
um you can change your TSR settings. You
can decrease like the time or like the
change the number of samples to try and
adjust um for that seam. Um, you can
also tune things like max roughness to
trace or like max rate intensity. Just
um adjust like how bright um or like
especially for noise um you'll see like
a trail of like sparkles when the frost
moves across sometimes. So if you
decrease that um it won't be as
reflective or shiny. So you might be
able to fix some of the seams that way.
Um you can also use DLSS and DLSS DLSSR
um to help u with denoising and
upscaling as well. Um we use those in
production. Those also give you an
additional performance boost because it
reduces the screen percentage that
you're rendering. So like you can render
at say like 80% screen percentage and
then let DLSS do the uprising on it.
So, another useful thing for artists,
especially if they don't have a cluster
to test the content on beforehand, is to
preview it in the editor. Um, you can
turn on the preview editor on the actor
directly, and you'll see it in your um
viewport um updating. It can be a bit
heavy on performance. Um, so previewing
the cluster, you won't be able to test
like performance and optimization as
much, but you can check for seams and
that kind of thing. You can also launch
the editor or launch end display
directly from the editor using the end
display quick launch feature. Um, that
basically lets you launch as if you were
launching the node um on your machine.
So again, it won't be performant, but
you can see if there's going to be seams
or um other artifacts.
And big thing is still even though we
have a lot more render power, you still
need to optimize. Um like I think the
goal of having more render power is to
be able to achieve more photo realism,
add more detail. Um
so you still want to have optimized
content. It's not like you could just
throw anything at it, expect it to work.
Um, so use um use um insights and
profiling to um get better performance
beforehand. You probably want to have
like about 10 FPS overhead. Um so like
then when you get to shoot, you have
some room to adjust things or increase
like your overcan or resolution a little
bit. um but it's only going to run as
fast as the slowest node. So if you have
one particular section of your scene
that's more problematic, the whole scene
is going to run um to as fast as it can
render that. So that's something to keep
in mind.
Um so here's a bunch of sears that

Yeah.
Yeah, lots of sea bars. Um, there's also

probably don't need to touch those that
much. Um, most of it you can handle in

Um, but these are some handy ones just
to use.
And then testing and troubleshooting.
So definitely use Wireshark. um check
for any drop packets. Um you can use
analyzers like fabrics to check the
signal or generate a simp stream if you
want to test outside of Unreal. Um just
to check your network. Um
definitely monitor the network usage.
You could just use the one in task
manager. That was fine. Um just to see
how much is being sent out. And the big
one is definitely check the logs cuz
it's pretty hard to diagnose things on a
cluster especially if you have a lot of
nodes. You have to kind of go through
all of them and see which one has the
issue. So
I think one way to approach it is just
try to um isolate the issue. So maybe
first try testing end to end. Um, you
can test um as a media source and output
um just from two editors um as a sender
receiver. You can also test on the same
node, but um it's probably best to test
on two separate ones. Um so here's some
like setup of like setting up the media
output, setting up the media source, and
then if it's working, um it should be
like that last picture where you where
you'll see the viewport or like the
camera view. um in your um both your
media sender and receiver.
Um I think one of the most frustrating
issues is when you get a black frustr
um it usually means that the config or
rivermax wasn't set up correctly. Um so
check the log. If you see something like
um that um bit of the um output log up
there, you'll see like the error. Um
it's not very descriptive error message.
So it says it wasn't installed or like
not initialized. It was actually the
wrong version of the SDK. So go back and
double check that. Um make sure that um
you follow the steps. Um, I'll put a
link to the um Unreal Simpy setup guide
that has a lot of set steps for like any
environment variables and things to make
sure they're set. Um,
also check that your multiccast
addresses and stuff are set up
correctly. In 56, it actually does a lot
of that config for you. Um, so it'll
make a unique multiccast address for
each of the streams and connect um,
which ones are inputs and outputs for
you. Um, but something to double check.
And also another one is that uh, if it's
not using the right timing source, it'll
also come out black. Um, so double check
that you have it set to PDP if you're
